Any graph on `n` vertices has at most `n.choose 2` edges.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {G : SimpleGraph V} [inst : Fintype ↑G.edgeSet] [inst_1 : Fintype V],
  G.edgeFinset.card ≤ (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_le_card_choose_two
docString: Any graph on `n` vertices has at most `n.choose 2` edges.

The number of edges in a graph with n vertices is at most n choose 2.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {G : SimpleGraph V} [inst : Fintype ↑G.edgeSet] [inst_1 : Fintype V],
  G.edgeFinset.card ≤ (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_le_card_choose_two
docString: The number of edges in a graph with n vertices is at most n choose 2.

This theorem states that for any given graph 'G' with vertex set 'V', the number of edges in 'G' is at most the binomial coefficient "n choose 2", where 'n' is the number of vertices in 'V'. This is a consequence of the fact that any pair of distinct vertices can contribute at most one edge, and there are "n choose 2" such pairs in a graph with 'n' vertices.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} {G : SimpleGraph V} [inst : Fintype ↑G.edgeSet] [inst_1 : Fintype V],
  G.edgeFinset.card ≤ (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_le_card_choose_two
docString: This theorem states that for any given graph 'G' with vertex set 'V', the number of edges in 'G' is at most the binomial coefficient "n choose 2", where 'n' is the number of vertices in 'V'. This is a consequence of the fact that any pair of distinct vertices can contribute at most one edge, and there are "n choose 2" such pairs in a graph with 'n' vertices.

The complete graph on `n` vertices has `n.choose 2` edges.

type: ∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableEq V], ⊤.edgeFinset.card = (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_top_eq_card_choose_two
docString: The complete graph on `n` vertices has `n.choose 2` edges.

The complete graph on a finite set of `n` vertices has `n choose 2` edges.

type: ∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableEq V], ⊤.edgeFinset.card = (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_top_eq_card_choose_two
docString: The complete graph on a finite set of `n` vertices has `n choose 2` edges.

This theorem states that the complete graph on `n` vertices has `n.choose 2` edges. Here, `V` represents the set of vertices and is assumed to be a finite type (`Fintype V`). `DecidableEq V` means that equality between two vertices can be definitively determined. The notation `⊤.edgeFinset.card` represents the number of edges in the complete graph on `V`, and `(Fintype.card V).choose 2` is the binomial coefficient "n choose 2", which corresponds to the number of ways to choose 2 elements from a set of `n` elements. Thus, the theorem asserts that the number of edges in a complete graph with `n` vertices is equal to the number of ways to choose 2 vertices from the `n` vertices, which is what is expected in a complete graph since every pair of distinct vertices is connected by an edge.

type: ∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableEq V], ⊤.edgeFinset.card = (Fintype.card V).choose 2
name: SimpleGraph.card_edgeFinset_top_eq_card_choose_two
docString: This theorem states that the complete graph on `n` vertices has `n.choose 2` edges. Here, `V` represents the set of vertices and is assumed to be a finite type (`Fintype V`). `DecidableEq V` means that equality between two vertices can be definitively determined. The notation `⊤.edgeFinset.card` represents the number of edges in the complete graph on `V`, and `(Fintype.card V).choose 2` is the binomial coefficient "n choose 2", which corresponds to the number of ways to choose 2 elements from a set of `n` elements. Thus, the theorem asserts that the number of edges in a complete graph with `n` vertices is equal to the number of ways to choose 2 vertices from the `n` vertices, which is what is expected in a complete graph since every pair of distinct vertices is connected by an edge.

A graph has edge-disjoint triangles if each edge belongs to at most one triangle.

type: {α : Type u_1} → SimpleGraph α → Prop
name: SimpleGraph.EdgeDisjointTriangles
docString: A graph has edge-disjoint triangles if each edge belongs to at most one triangle.

There is an equivalence between the set of edges incident to a given
vertex and the set of vertices adjacent to the vertex.

type: {V : Type u} → (G : SimpleGraph V) → [inst : DecidableEq V] → (v : V) → ↑(G.incidenceSet v) ≃ ↑(G.neighborSet v)
name: SimpleGraph.incidenceSetEquivNeighborSet
docString:
There is an equivalence between the set of edges incident to a given
vertex and the set of vertices adjacent to the vertex.

The maximum degree of a nonempty graph is less than the number of vertices. Note that the assumption
that `V` is nonempty is necessary, as otherwise this would assert the existence of a
natural number less than zero.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} (G : SimpleGraph V) [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableRel G.Adj] [inst_2 : Nonempty V],
  G.maxDegree < Fintype.card V
name: SimpleGraph.maxDegree_lt_card_verts
docString:
The maximum degree of a nonempty graph is less than the number of vertices. Note that the assumption
that `V` is nonempty is necessary, as otherwise this would assert the existence of a
natural number less than zero.

There exists a vertex of maximal degree. Note the assumption of being nonempty is necessary, as
the lemma implies there exists a vertex.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} (G : SimpleGraph V) [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableRel G.Adj] [inst_2 : Nonempty V],
  ∃ v, G.maxDegree = G.degree v
name: SimpleGraph.exists_maximal_degree_vertex
docString:
There exists a vertex of maximal degree. Note the assumption of being nonempty is necessary, as
the lemma implies there exists a vertex.

The path graph on `n` vertices.

type: (n : ℕ) → SimpleGraph (Fin n)
name: SimpleGraph.pathGraph
docString: The path graph on `n` vertices.

There exists a vertex of minimal degree. Note the assumption of being nonempty is necessary, as
the lemma implies there exists a vertex.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} (G : SimpleGraph V) [inst : Fintype V] [inst_1 : DecidableRel G.Adj] [inst_2 : Nonempty V],
  ∃ v, G.minDegree = G.degree v
name: SimpleGraph.exists_minimal_degree_vertex
docString:
There exists a vertex of minimal degree. Note the assumption of being nonempty is necessary, as
the lemma implies there exists a vertex.

An edge of a graph is a *bridge* if, after removing it, its incident vertices
are no longer reachable from one another.

type: {V : Type u} → SimpleGraph V → Sym2 V → Prop
name: SimpleGraph.IsBridge
docString:
An edge of a graph is a *bridge* if, after removing it, its incident vertices
are no longer reachable from one another.

O(n). True if the trees have the same elements, ignoring structural differences.

Equiv {1, 2, 4} {2, 1, 1, 4} = true
Equiv {1, 2, 4} {1, 2, 3} = false

type: {α : Type u_1} → Ordnode α → Ordnode α → Prop
name: Ordnode.Equiv
docString:
O(n). True if the trees have the same elements, ignoring structural differences.

Equiv {1, 2, 4} {2, 1, 1, 4} = true
Equiv {1, 2, 4} {1, 2, 3} = false

The cardinality of the antidiagonal of `n` is `n + 1`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), (Finset.antidiagonal n).card = n + 1
name: Finset.Nat.card_antidiagonal
docString: The cardinality of the antidiagonal of `n` is `n + 1`.

Asymptotic lower bound on the **Ruzsa-Szemerédi problem**.

There exists a graph with `n` vertices and `Ω((n ^ 2 * exp (-4 * sqrt (log n))))` edges such that
each edge belongs to exactly one triangle.

type: (fun n => ↑n ^ 2 * Real.exp (-4 * √(Real.log ↑n))) =O[Filter.atTop] fun n => ↑(ruzsaSzemerediNumberNat n)
name: ruzsaSzemerediNumberNat_asymptotic_lower_bound
docString:
Asymptotic lower bound on the **Ruzsa-Szemerédi problem**.

There exists a graph with `n` vertices and `Ω((n ^ 2 * exp (-4 * sqrt (log n))))` edges such that
each edge belongs to exactly one triangle.

Explicit lower bound on the **Ruzsa-Szemerédi problem**.

There exists a graph with `n` vertices and
`(n / 3 - 2) * (n - 3) / 6 * exp (-4 * sqrt (log ((n - 3) / 6)))` edges such that each edge belongs
to exactly one triangle.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), (↑n / 3 - 2) * ↑((n - 3) / 6) * Real.exp (-4 * √(Real.log ↑((n - 3) / 6))) ≤ ↑(ruzsaSzemerediNumberNat n)
name: ruzsaSzemerediNumberNat_lower_bound
docString:
Explicit lower bound on the **Ruzsa-Szemerédi problem**.

There exists a graph with `n` vertices and
`(n / 3 - 2) * (n - 3) / 6 * exp (-4 * sqrt (log ((n - 3) / 6)))` edges such that each edge belongs
to exactly one triangle.

The cardinality of the antidiagonal of `n` is `n+1`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), (Multiset.Nat.antidiagonal n).card = n + 1
name: Multiset.Nat.card_antidiagonal
docString: The cardinality of the antidiagonal of `n` is `n+1`.

The edge set of an Eulerian graph is finite.

type:
{V : Type u_1} →
  {G : SimpleGraph V} → [inst : DecidableEq V] → {u v : V} → {p : G.Walk u v} → p.IsEulerian → Fintype ↑G.edgeSet
name: SimpleGraph.Walk.IsEulerian.fintypeEdgeSet
docString: The edge set of an Eulerian graph is finite.

Two vertices are adjacent iff there is an edge between them. The
condition `v ≠ w` ensures they are different endpoints of the edge,
which is necessary since when `v = w` the existential
`∃ (e ∈ G.edgeSet), v ∈ e ∧ w ∈ e` is satisfied by every edge
incident to `v`.

type: ∀ {V : Type u} {G : SimpleGraph V} {v w : V}, G.Adj v w ↔ v ≠ w ∧ ∃ e ∈ G.edgeSet, v ∈ e ∧ w ∈ e
name: SimpleGraph.adj_iff_exists_edge
docString:
Two vertices are adjacent iff there is an edge between them. The
condition `v ≠ w` ensures they are different endpoints of the edge,
which is necessary since when `v = w` the existential
`∃ (e ∈ G.edgeSet), v ∈ e ∧ w ∈ e` is satisfied by every edge
incident to `v`.

**Turán's theorem**. `turanGraph n r` is, up to isomorphism, the unique
`r + 1`-cliquefree Turán-maximal graph on `n` vertices.

type:
∀ {V : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype V] {G : SimpleGraph V} [inst_1 : DecidableRel G.Adj] {r : ℕ},
  0 < r → (G.IsTuranMaximal r ↔ Nonempty (G ≃g SimpleGraph.turanGraph (Fintype.card V) r))
name: SimpleGraph.isTuranMaximal_iff_nonempty_iso_turanGraph
docString:
**Turán's theorem**. `turanGraph n r` is, up to isomorphism, the unique
`r + 1`-cliquefree Turán-maximal graph on `n` vertices.

Equivalence between Dyck words of semilength `n` and rooted binary trees with
`n` internal nodes.

type: (n : ℕ) → { p // p.semilength = n } ≃ { x // x ∈ Tree.treesOfNumNodesEq n }
name: DyckWord.equivTreesOfNumNodesEq
docString:
Equivalence between Dyck words of semilength `n` and rooted binary trees with
`n` internal nodes.

Turning an edge in the spanning tree into a loop gives the identity loop.

type:
∀ {G : Type u} [inst : CategoryTheory.Groupoid G] [inst_1 : IsFreeGroupoid G]
  (T : WideSubquiver (Quiver.Symmetrify (IsFreeGroupoid.Generators G)))
  [inst_2 : Quiver.Arborescence (WideSubquiver.toType (Quiver.Symmetrify (IsFreeGroupoid.Generators G)) T)]
  {a b : IsFreeGroupoid.Generators G},
  ∀ e ∈ Quiver.wideSubquiverSymmetrify T a b,
    IsFreeGroupoid.SpanningTree.loopOfHom T (IsFreeGroupoid.of e) =
      CategoryTheory.CategoryStruct.id (IsFreeGroupoid.SpanningTree.root'✝ T)
name: IsFreeGroupoid.SpanningTree.loopOfHom_eq_id
docString: Turning an edge in the spanning tree into a loop gives the identity loop.

Theorem of bark and tree: if a set is within a preconnected set and its closure, then it is
preconnected as well. See also `IsConnected.subset_closure`.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] {s t : Set α}, IsPreconnected s → s ⊆ t → t ⊆ closure s → IsPreconnected t
name: IsPreconnected.subset_closure
docString:
Theorem of bark and tree: if a set is within a preconnected set and its closure, then it is
preconnected as well. See also `IsConnected.subset_closure`.
